Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Research: Causes and Consequences of Exceptional Diversity in Spiny-Rayed Fishes
Award.AbstractNarration:
Spiny-rayed fishes are one of the most successful radiations of vertebrate animals, with about 17,000 species and astonishing morphological and ecological diversity that includes many culturally and economically important species such as tunas, flounders, seahorses, largemouth bass, and guppies. This diverse group represents one of the last great frontiers to understand vertebrate evolution. In this project, the evolutionary relationships among more than 260 families of these fishes will be studied with several methods of phylogenetic inference using DNA sequence data from 16 protein-coding nuclear genes from specimens of 1,500 species. The phylogenetic trees depicting evolutionary relationships among these groups will be combined with more than 40 fossil calibration points to produce a time-calibrated branching diagram of the evolutionary history of these fishes. This time-calibrated phylogeny and a large data set of functionally important anatomical characteristics of the feeding and locomotor systems from over 1,000 species will then be used to compare the rates of speciation and rates of morphological evolution in lineages that live in the five major habitat types: coral reefs, temperate reefs, near-shore soft bottom, pelagic marine, and freshwater. There is a strong theoretical expectation from previous work that freshwater lineages will show high rates of speciation while coral reefs will show the highest rates of speciation and morphological evolution, but these expectations have never been addressed empirically.

This research will strengthen our understanding of the evolutionary relationships and major evolutionary dynamics of the most successful radiation of vertebrate animals on the earth today. Over 20,000 new gene sequences and the morphological data set from over 1,000 species will be made available to the scientific community. The project will support the development of three postdoctoral scholars and has a major undergraduate training program.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The major outcomes of this award were to produce a robust phylogenetic hypothesis of the major groups of ray-finned fishes and to conduct analyses of the rate of diversification through time and the role of major anatomical innovations in shaping the diversity of this major group that makes up over half of all living vertebrates. Work with this phylogeny revealed that few changes in the net rate of speciation have occurred within this group and that there is no evidence of what was an expected change in speciation or extinction through the end-Cretaceous mass extinction event. Several increases in rates of speciation were associated with the invasion of polar or deep ocean habitats, countering the expectation that warm, tropical regions drive high rates of diversification. Defensive spines in the fins were shown to have evolved independently in at least four different instances in fishes and were shown to cause fish body shapes to increase along the dimensions in which the spines are oriented. Fish with spines in the dorsal and anal fin are deeper bodied than fish without these spines. A major reorganization of the pharyngeal jaw apparatus, a novel jaw located in the throat of all ray-finned fishes, was traditionally thought to have evolved only once but the new phylogeny led to the finding that this major innovation has evolved at least five times independently and in two cases led to extremely diverse groups of fishes. The success of at least two groups of fishes strongly supports the role of this innovation in contributing to the ecological diversity of fishes.  However, not all effects of the innovation are positive. It was shown that this innovation, while key to the diversification of cichlid fishes, results in a decreased ability to eat other fish. In some instances, such as the mass extinction of cichlids in Africa’s Lake Victoria in association with the human introduction of the highly efficient fish-eating Nile perch, the innovation lead to reduced competitive ability in the face of an efficient predator that lacks the innovation, thus revealing that even major innovations are not beneficial in all circumstances.

   This project contributes to our understanding of the history of life on earth by providing a strong phylogeny of fishes that provides a framework for understanding evolutionary relationships and by extension the sequence of many important events in fish history. Demonstration of how several major innovations and ecological transitions have impacted fish evolution contributes to our understanding of key evolutionary events in life’s history. Several research personnel received invaluable training during this research in methods for phylogenetic reconstruction, the application of phylogenetics to comparative questions, fish anatomy, fish functional morphology and fish ecology. The project provided major support for one female postdoctoral researcher and three doctoral students, two of which were female. Over 40 undergraduate students participated in the project, learning skills in phylogenetics, fish anatomy and fish ecology. Presentations on this research were made by more than ten researchers in a wide range of venues from university seminars, to scientific conferences, public interest groups in conservation and fish biodiversity, and secondary school classrooms.
